B663BFBC09974D97A628200248ED4231.description: The New Testament promises new heavens and a new earth (2 Peter 3:13; Revelations 21:1). Romans 8:18-25 teaches that the creation is awaiting redemption also.  When our bodies are redeemed, the creation will itself be set free from its corruption.  Also the meek will inherit the earth (Matthew 5:5), and Abraham will be heir of the world (Romans 4:13).

C64F3CAD50C94A479D58E1CB47DF3852.description: The future hope of an earthly kingdom ruled by the Messiah remained the expectation of the disciples. Though Christ told them they could not know the time of the visible arrival of the kingdom, He did not deny their understanding of its nature (Acts 1:6-8) The New Testament also speaks of resurrected believers ruling with Christ (2 Timothy 2:12; Romans 5:17; Romans 4:13; 1 Corinthians 6:2-3).

34A5C7B1CAC54AE8AFB72149A3D4F457.description: The Old Testament predicted the coming of the Messiah, Who will rule over the earth from Zion.  This new earth will be an abundantly fruitful place in which sin and its effects do not exist (Psalm 2:6; 14:7; 53:6; 110:2; Isaiah 2:1-4; 11-12; 65:17-19; Jeremiah 31:1-12; Joel 3:17-18).

AA8B29D31263455D84D6781E095DD2DC.description: New heavens and the new earth

63A6EE014F9243BDB2B72B11BDE5848E.description: Punishment of the wicked is just (Isaiah 66:24; Revelation 19:1-3).

47B704D8AF7446F3904AF1898076E25C.description: Punishment of the wicked is conscious (Revelation 14:11).

8FE68F32C09C421DAF2320FED59C305D.description: Punishment of the wicked is eternal (Isaiah 66:24; Matthew 25:41; Mark 9:43-48; Revelation 14:11; 20:10).

CD84FF0519A6467DAC8967C3D2CDAE4F.description: Lake of Fire                    The Lake  of Fire/Gehenna (often translated as hell) is a place of torment that God has  prepared for the Devil, his angels, and all those who do not repent of their sin (Matthew 25:41; Mark 9:43-48; Revelation 21:8).

BB1E7408BC7D4F838A01DC064B1E5D04.description: The unsaved dead will be raised from Hades to stand with the unsaved living to be judged by Christ at the Great White Throne (Revelation 20:11-15).

7F45F88B318B42BD8FA27ABC9A9A1A66.description: At the end of the Millennium, Christ will defeat Satan's final rebellion against His rule (Revelation 20:7-10).

3E025B4EC3AF401CBFC911F57A186942.description: Reining with Christ                God's people will reign with Christ over the earth for one thousand years (Revelation 20:4-6).

C8F5F2FFC5F54FC590CF9DF5AC2A0872.description: Long Life                     Death will become a rare event, and long life will be considered normal.  Anyone who dies at the age of one hundred will be considered a child (Isaiah 65:20).

32429086D0C34FE297B314256641F57B.description: Millennium    God will restore the earth to a condition that foreshadows the full restoration of the new creation.  The earth will be an abundantly fruitful place in which drought and disaster are confined to specific judgments  (Isaiah 65-66; Zechariah 14; Revelation 20).

75E0DF77A79543D29BC38D8E378C4369.description: Christ will conquer His enemies, bind Satan for one thousand years, and fully establish His rule on earth (Revelation 19:11-20; 3).

C411FDCFFBD244129855ED718B3E157E.description: When Christ returns, the kingdoms of this earth will become the kingdom of God (Revelation 11:15).

D7360E20DA8F4981B33BCAE08ACB2D46.description: The Tribulation will be a time of great persecution against God's people (Revelation 11:7-8; 13:17).

BDD763DC5A06489280689AB2B7EB886A.description: During this time Satan will exercise extensive control over the earth through the Antichrist and False Prophet (2 Thessalonians 2:3-4; Revelation 13; 17-18).

3EDBB39082A04A248EE9B985F6A28F6B.description: The Tribulation will be a seven year period of God's judgement on the world (Daniel 9:24-27; 12:11-12; Revelation 11:2-3; 12:14).

65B57245320A41DB9B43DFCDD261297A.description: Christ has promised the He will come suddenly and unexpectedly (Matthew 24:36-39, 42-44; 35:13; Luke 12:40; 1 Thessalonians 5:2).

10E160951A39416B9270E61CB21A43F2.description: Christ has promised to keep His church from the hour of trial that is coming on the whole world (Revelations 3:10).

E14719FE70F44A7D90A931B813BD6732.description: The Rapture will occur before the Tribulation.

480C73067B1B4AD59948241334452436.description: At the Rapture the dead in Christ will rise first, and those who are still alive will be caught up with them to meet Christ in the air (1 Thessalonians 4:13-18).

05E5D4A5A1124CE4BBB83CC2E62B4F4D.description: The Doctrine of the End Times (Eschatology)

40D641A68FAB41FDB8FEE5DD0F3760AC.description: Confession of sin is a means for the church to progress in santification.

104B9AE08C2742D4B8A0C6459C297A1F.description: Intercession honors God by demonstrating the church's dependence on Him for all that i does.  Intercession is also a key way for the church to love and help the members of the body.

1C84E1104D134EEA9981E63C3598D910.description: Praise honors God by ascribing to Him the glory He deserves.

C418D4B596A14EE3BFBF0EE9B5B12D62.description: Prayer  Prayer is an essential part of the church's activity, both corporately and individually (Acts 2:42).

A529C1A29ED6454FABBEB0A5A922C68B.description: Fellowship  In the church, believers are to encourage, edify, and help one another.  This work is an essential part of Christians showing the love of Christ (Acts 2:42; John 13:35; Ephesians 4:15-16).

0861DA4699A64FD89282F24D72AC9F24.description: The Lord's Supper is the ordinance by which believers are to remember that Christ instituted the New Covenant through His sacrifice on the cross for them as they anticipate his Second Coming (1 Corinthians 11:23-26).

CD862E1F0C074ED1881F8D8B7BF7A952.description: Baptism  Baptism is an ordinance that symbolizes our union with Christ in His death, burial and Resurrection, which is accomplished through the baptism of the Holy Spirit which brings people into the body of Christ (Romans 6:3-4; Colossians 2:12; 1 Corinthians 12:13).

81BBC7B8E1284B148B8DBAE856EA9E52.description: Administration of the ordinances   Ordinances are actions of obedience, commanded and explained in Scripture and practiced by the New Testament church.  Believers carry out the ordainence , not to obtain grace but rather to testify that they have already received grace.

7CFC4180F2644FA9971916FC360266D2.description: Ministry of the Word  Central to the church's mission is the reading of Scripture and the preaching of the Word (Acts 2:42; 1 Timothy 4:13; 2 Timothy 4:2) Through the reading and exposition of Scripture, the church is built up and the lost are evangilized (Ephesians 5:12; Romans 10:14).

0A59DB4684084F8B95D2EC437D8D5446.description: The entire congregation is to be involved in the work of church discipline (Matthew 18:15-17; 1 Corinthians 1:2; 5:4-5).

3192FF6F753D4280896F53EC91CB8FD5.description: The congregation is to decide who will extend the influence of the church in missionary endeavors (Acts 13:1-3).

6F3EDC9BA3F04420A1118053C00E292D.description: The entire congregation should be involved in choosing its leadership (Acts 1:13-26; 6:1-6).

2CDB7AB1900348A3AC393D541B417EB4.description: Deacons must meet certain qualifications ( 1 Timothy 3:8-13).

815C419949604DCF999BCCF258F92D81.description: The deacons are designated to free the elders to focus on preaching the Word and prayer (Acts 6:1-6)

5EFB9A75A5784BD7B95B8C21F1443336.description: The deacons were chosen to focus on meeting material needs of church members (Acts 6:1-6).

FCFA80D1CE2944BB874DA897D9B9CB3C.description: An elder is to be a man who is gifted in teacheing and whose character is above reproach (1 Timothy 3:1-7).

666928D21AAE47E080F24794D0F54CF0.description: The elders are to oversee and shepherd the people entrusted to their care (Acts 20:28; 1 Timothy 3:1; Titus 1:7; 1 Peter 5:2).

F218805FF4334A34A426934BB77FF2D3.description: Overseer (bishop), elder, and pastor are different titles or the same office (Acts 20:17, 28)

8F3053B7CC034C20B865FDDC1D994C5B.description: Head   Jesus Christ is the head of the church.   Therefore, all church leadership is subject to His authority (Ephesians 1:22; 4:15; 5:23; Colossians 1:18; 2:10, 19).

ED1FF6FC60AF442CBBDE7DE194DE65E2.description: Universal church   Paul sometimes speaks of the church as a single community (Ephesians 4:4; 5:25).

2DE0B45E15454AB2A8657A9FC4727BF2.description: Regional church   One can refer to the church of Judea, Galilee, and Samaria (Acts 9:31), though the church of that region is made up of many smaller assemblies.

8DEE7CFD891041028DFACF2EFE41DC8E.description: Local church  Paul refers to a church that meets in a house (Romans 16:5).

FA896B84EF6C4FC0A40D1A4A3B2D577E.description: Invisible church  The invisible church consists of all who are truly regenerated by the Spirit (1 Corinthians 12:13; Colossians 1:13).

02F35026F0F94987BFC015B09A242EE9.description: Visible church  The visible church consists of local churches, comprising those who profess faith in Christ.  Not all in the visible church are truly regenerated (1 Corinthians 1:2; Acts 20:29-30; Revelations 2-3).

1226396C8EAC43D886708D5E8311FF12.description: Day of Pentecost  Jesus Christ poured our His Spirit on His followers on the day of Pentecost. Until that time His followers were commanded to wait for the Spirit's coming (Acts 1:4-5; 2:1-42).

7067850933D34ED1A91482FCA0D7C1DA.description: The Spirit's indwelling of believers forms the people of God into the body of Christ (1 Corinthians 12:13).

F2F79D1ED5014C94AB83B164C4CCE367.description: Whereas Israel worshiped at a temple, of the Holy Spirit, the church is the temple of the Holy Spirit (1 Corinthians 3:16; Ephesians 2:22).

60232E87F04C4858995031E85912B550.description: The church is a new entity, established by the New Covenant, and it includes both Jews and Gentiles (Ephesians 2:14-16).

F76DFA7BDAC549F59A7D086F9FBEB7DE.description: Founded by the gift of the Holy Spirit. The church is the New Covenant community formed through the promised indwelling of the Holy Spirit.

2C25874DF1594C589775A59075B55DB5.description: Subsequent to the ministry of Christ Jesus prophesied that the church was a xoming entity that He would found through His apostles and prophets (Matthew 16:18; Ephesians 2:20).

943F03F70D1A4B5F9A85C92DB428B044.description: Origin of the church  It is reasonable to conclude that the church started at Pentecost .

715ADC3B56E3487983663D7392B0D32B.description: Definition of the church The church is the assembly of believers who are brought together through the baptism of the Holy Spirit to serve as the body of Christ and the present manifestation of His Kingdom (Matthew 16:18-19;  Acts 2:41-47;  1 Corinthians 12:13; Colossians 1:13).

D8F3D2C467B549D8928126ADB107971D.description: Renewal of all creation  God will fully restore man's dominion over the created order.  Creation will be redeemed to its orignal glory and goodness (Hebrews 2:5-9; Revelation 21:4; 22:5).

EF60DC006E054400B95BD103A365DDA2.description: Resurrection  Dead believer will be resurrected, and living believers will be given new bodies. These bodies will be free from pain, sorrow and death (1 Corinthians 15:42-45; Romans 8:18, 23).

48C2B8B987B645558C422B63B4F80CA8.description: Moral perfection  All believers who have not died will be completely delivered from all aspects of sin  ( 1 Corinthians 15:55-57;  Titus 2:11-14; 1 Peter 1:13; 1 John 3:2).

024E9B678FD04A8D849B5CD4F5F42B21.description: Timing  God will glorify believers at the second coming of Christ (1 Corinthians 15:12-23; 1 Peter 1:13; 1 John 3:2).

53B578EDFC3244A2BFA591552874AC51.description: Definition  Glorification is God's exaltation of the believer to be freed from all the effects of sin and restored completely to the work of exercising dominion over the earth (Romans 8:18-30; Ephesians 1:13-14; 1 Peter 1:3-5).

3E11010D0A6C40D0BFCBBEFCD92495FF.description: Goal of sanctification  The purpose of sanctification is to make the believer like Jesus Christ, Who is His humanity, empowered by the Holy Spirit, was the perfect image-bearer of God (Romans 8:28-29; Colossians 3:10; Hebrew 1:2-3).  The process of sanctification is not complete in the is life.  Only when the believer leaves this life and is untied with the Savior is he fully sanctified (Hebrew 12:23; 1 JOhn 1:8; 3:2).

81D8A5A6B13848BCB5C8BF3074503E16.description: Cooperative      Sanctification is a cooperative work.  The Holy Spirit (through the Bible and other means) directs, encourages and empowers the believer to grow spiritually.  But the believer also has responsibility, He must submit to the leading of the Spirit and follow His direction (John 17:17, Romans 6:1-12; 8:1-17; Galatians 5:16-26; 1 Thessalonians 4:1-3; Philippians 2:12-13; 1 Peter 1:15).

83917E272FE844B0A01F40C891CEE2A6.description: Ongoing      Unlike justification and regeneration which happens in a moment-God's work of sanctification is a process.  From regeneration until  death, the believer becomes less given to sin and more given to obeying God and delighting in Him (2 Corinthians 3:18; Phillipians 1:6).

60796DCE373E41E392AB866D09B56A76.description: Definition  Sanctification is God's ongoing work of making the believer more like Himself. In justification, God declares the sinner righteous.  In sanctification, He enables the believer to live righteously (Romans 6:17-19; 8:1-5).

1D60BED87CEE493D8B414D1CF418C335.description: Results of justification  Because of justification the believer is completely forgiven.  God is no longer angry with him because He considers him to be righteous (Romans 4:6-8; 8:1, 33-34). Also because of justification God remains just even though He forgives the guilty ans saves them from sin (Romans 6:17-19; 8:1-5).

80CA5CCB8F6E4D41A03B99F2CD5BCF2D.description: Condition for Justification  There is only one condition for experiencing justification.  The sinner must believe the gospel. Although many have claimed that justification is by faith and works, the Bible clearly teachers that faith alone is the condition for justification (John 3:18; Romans 3:28; 4:4-5; Galatians 2:16).

A6F5CA7AF20F402088EEBD0B2E7D7CBF.description: Basis of justification  God pronounces the believing sinner righteous based on Christ's work.  In particular, God gives the believer the righteousness of Christ. God, therefore, considers the believer to be righteous as Jesus Christ (Matthew 3:15, Romans 3:21-25; 5:17-19; Galatians 4:4).

4D2BCCCBD6CA417483CAAE4D53AA938E.description: Need for justification God is just. He punishes the guilty and rewards the innocent.  But all humans are guilty before God.  God cannot forgive sinners unless their standing before Him is changed (Genesis 18:25; Proverbs 17:15; Romans 3:19-20).

2BF065CC45494B6685A5A34194FEB195.description: Definition Justification is God's work of declaring  the believing sinner righteous because of what Christ has dome (Roman's 3:24-25).

EAD1FB7EA2D7454FA3121EBB4BA1FE35.description: Results of regeneration. God's work of regeneration produces a new life.  The believer dies to sin so that he is no longer enslaved to it.  He becomes alive to God and capable of obeying Him (Romans 6:1-11; 2 Corinthians 5:15; 17; Ephesians 2:4-10; 1 John 2:29).

8A1D9D4F91204D25B8BADBCB4E0E39C9.description: Need for regeneration. Because of the Fall, humans love sin and hate God. They do not want to commune with God, and they are not able to obey Him.  If sinners are to experience God's salvation, they must receive a new heart  (Romans  3:9-20; 1 Corinthians 2:14; Ephesians :1-3).

B9B43CBB35304485B4D19DC510D58473.description: Definition-Regenerated literally means "born again."  Regeneration is God's work of changing the nature of the sinner so that he loves what is good and hates what is evil (Ezekial 11:19-20; John 3:3-8, 19*21).

DEDA0331E7B046118E10CCA8679176C2.description: Repentance and faith are inseparable.  Turning away from sin and trusting God for pardon are two aspects of one action (Isaiah 55:6-7; Mark 1:15; Acts 20:21; Hebrew 6:1).

F4BBAE6F9F394A95AC9561BF74F2CFB0.description: Genuine faith is more than mere mental assent to the facts of the gospel. The true believer trust in Jesus's death and Resurrection to save him from sin (John 1:12; 2:23-25; Acts 10:43; Romans 4:5; 1 John 5:13).

C62B9D0541EA4641AAA61BCB810DF3C5.description: Repentance is necessary for conversion.  Without repentance, there is no conversion (Matthew 4:17; Luke 24:46-47; Acts 17:30).

BEDED8CBEC6A42CD85066B0A64BD4128.description: Repentance is a gift from God to the sinner (acts 11:18; 2 Timothy 2:25)

D3855D882502434898A3A878E5143184.description: Repentance is the sinner's change of mind regarding sin. It involves godly sorrow for sin and a turning away from it (2 Chronicles 7:14; Ezekiel 33:11; Matthew 3:8; 2 Corinthians 7:9-10; Hebrews 12:17).

08CD5ECD73F24703BCABCDE4388E2573.description: Conversion-The doctrine of salvation primarily concerns what God does for the sinner. The doctrine of conversion concerns how the sinner is to receive the gospel message.  There are two aspects to conversion.

3C16EF630CD54CD389C8288898D9B027.description: God's command to preach.  God commands His people to present the gospel to everyone (Matthew 28:18-20).

E84C9EE63E934F1D8C19074495C4FC0A.description: God's displeasure. God does not take pleasure in the death of the wicked (Ezekiel 18:23, 32; 33:11; 2 Peter 3:9).

11C54E76D5704B41838EBB68E1F7FC73.description: God's command to repent. God commands all people everywhere to repent and trust Christ for salvation (Acts 17:30).

68934C1630D64745AD17A8CF1712850A.description: Certainty-The people God has chosen will not fail to receive His salvation.  God does not change His mind, so His elect will remain His elect for all eternity  (John 5:37; 15:16; Romans 8:29-30; 9:15-16; 11:29).

EA0AF47394AA45D6B954874318020507.description: Timing-God chose his people before He created the world (Ephesians 1:4; 2 Thessalonians  2:13).

B72FA341E5F54D40858DBBB8450AD7D2.description: Definition-Election is God's gracious choice to favor some people with the salvation that Jesus Christ purchased (Ephesians 1:3-5; Acts 13:48; 2 Thessalonians  2:13).

0D45F54259064DD98410DE82EDC2AF78.description: The indwelling Spirit enables Christians to live as children of God rather than as slaves to the flesh (Galatians 5:16; Romans 8:9-17).

DA7666EEA155429EB45B035A37276F22.description: In the New Covenant, God promised to put His Spirit within His people in order to solve their sin problem (Exekiel 36:25-27).

564443208D1D49309ABB5507F20AA0F5.description: The presence of the Spirit in a person's life evidences the person's salvation (Romans 8:16).

258FAD461D7445C783B402B43312EFC4.description: The Holy Spirit is involved in regeneration (Ezekiel  36:25-27; John 3:5-8).

E0B749120ED143A7B73517EC3EBEDB7C.description: Salvation of sinners                                                                                                                                                                                                               The Spirit of God gives new life to the sinner and make him part of the church, the body of Christ.

50D1428C2A5B4E1FAB901ACD365019E3.description: The Holy Spirit endows the members of the church with spiritual gifts so that they are able to fulfill their ministry to others (John 7:39; 3:5-8; Acts 2:16-18; Romans 12:3-8;  1 Corinthians 12:1-31;  1 Peter 4:10-11).

095BD117E21B4D26925269F85504E6A0.description: The Holy Spirit empowered Jesus for His ministry on earth (Matthew 4:1; 12:28; Mark 1:10; Luke 4:18-21).

3A345AC6B50943D69E541000FAA6C053.description: The Holy Spirit empowered Israel's leaders for political and military service ( Numbers 11:16-29, Deuteronomy 34:9; Judges 6:34; 11:29; 13:25; 1 Samuel 16:13; Psalm 51:11) and for the construction of the tabernacle and the temple (Exodus 28:3; 31:1-11;  1 Chronicles 28:12; Haggai 2:5; Zechariah 4:6).

B876C814647D4ECBAD912C28A6486B2D.description: The Holy Spirit enabled people to prophesy (Numbers 11:25; 24:2; 1 Samuel 10:6, 10; 19:20;  2 Samuel 23:2; Nehemiah 9:20, 30) He is responsible for the inspiration of Scripture (1 Timothy 3:16; 2 Peter 1:21).

151D9D21DAF544598F914FA1EF4C5458.description: Empowerment for service.                                                                                                                                                                                                 The Holy Spirit is the member of the Trinity Who empowers people for service to God.

314F6480C2C04926A67EF32092ECC026.description: Creation and preservation.                                                                                                                                                                                                The Holy Spirit was involved in creating the world (Genesis 1:2; Job 26:13; 33:4; Psalm 33:6; 104:29-30) and continues to be involved in preserving the creation (Genesis 6:3; Job 34:14-15; Psalm 104:29-30).

1B9A64AC8F134142BC4039CA38103125.description: The Holy Spirit is a person.  The Spirit is not a force.  He possess the characteristics of a person ( Isaiah 11:2; John 14:26; 15:26; Romans 15:30; 1 Corinthians 12:11; Ephesians 4:30).

682AB1A01E834FE3808F545EC2747FBD.description: The Holy Spirit is God (See the Doctrine of God)

17C7C6609A804E619EEB23D59A491DAE.description: The Doctrine of the Holy Spirit (Pneumatology)

62BE7D0446F347258411DFDC75D5D018.description: Enthronement                                                                                                                                                                                                              God the Father has made Jesus Christ the King over all creation in fulfillment of His promises to David (2 Samuel  7:12-16, 18-19; Psalms 2:7-12; Acts 2:22-36).

16502B828BA04A6296FE1072FE72D8B0.description: Resurrection                                                                                                                                                                                                                  God the Father raised Jesus Christ from the dead giving Him and His people victory over the power of sin and death (Acts 2:24; 1 Corinthians 6:14; 15:54-56; Revelations 1:18).

E6989233CD7B4C92BA3DC747DA5BA4F5.description: God the Father has exalted Jesus Christ for His complete obedience (Philippians 2:9-11).

0C6E7A53676944F790D583C2DBE9B8AD.description: Passive obedience                                                                                                                                                                                                     Instead of claiming eternal life for Himself, Jesus Christ obeyed God the Father and died on the cross, receiving God's wrath so that sinners my receive the eternal life He had earned (Romans 3:25; 5:19; Philippians 2:8; Colossians 2:13-14).

FC45985BEA6F4B9C848C7A35040BF360.description: Active obedience                                                                                                                                                                                                        Jesus Christ became a man and perfectly obeyed all of God's law. Therefore, He earned eternal life for Himself as a man (Leviticus 18:5; Matthew 3:15; Romans 8:3; Galatians 4:4).

6DAF140B73374575B7270549569A7E8B.description: Jesus Christ is humbled Himself by submitting to His Father's will (Philippians  2:5-8).

E57F556DE48F4C098D14548013B19BCA.description: Jesus Christ fulfills His work in two stages.

48E3A2E1F326417AA6B23AC4C2BC9471.description: Christ will restore humans to the work of exercising dominion over the earth (Revelations 5:9-10; 22:5).

F4A042A45DC84AE9A773C12BFED3D026.description: Christ has complete authority and ability to exercise good and wise dominion over all things (Genesis 49:8-12; Matthew 28:18-20; Luke 1:26-33; Hebrews 2:5-9; Revelations 1:5).

6069CD8ECC194337B3C2EE2B35762FEA.description: Jesus Christ is the eternal King (Genesis 49:8-12; Matthew 28:18-20; Luke 1:26-33; Hebrews 2:5-9; Revelation 1:5; 5:9-10; 22:5).

EA1B2865721544E4B781907F41C2CB2A.description: Christ intercedes for His people (Romans 8:34; Hebrews 7:25).

B155636129664C87BB40198F5719169E.description: As a better priest of a better covenant, Christ fulfills and surpasses the priesthood of the Mosaic Law (Hebrew 7:18-19; 8:1-6).

B4B1970211864A68959A20B85D25EC45.description: Christ offered Himself as the perfect sacrifice for sinners (Isaiah 53:10-11; Acts 8:32-35; 1 Corinthians 5:7; Romans 3:25; Hebrews 2:17; 7;26-27; Revelations 5:6).

46A3BFC266E440A0A86BD1328A3861DA.description: Jesus Christ is the sinless Priest (Isaiah 53:10-11; Acts 8:32-35; 1 Corinthians 5:7; Romans3:25; 8:34; Hebrews 2:17; 7:25-27, 18-19; 8:1-6; Revelation 5:6).

78C77E05E99945219104CF8DA454AA62.description: Jesus is the Word of God the Father (John 1:1-18).

087D56B240754EDF9B823A21B0981EBD.description: Jesus is the prophet Who is greater than Moses (Deuteronomy 18:15-19; Acts 3:19-26; Hebrews 1:2; Revelations 1:1).

E69A6BF8CE5F455980522280937879A3.description: Christ declared God's word to the nations (Isaiah 42:1-4;49;6;50:4; Matthew 12:18-20; Hebrews 1:2).

22AA9AB12FFB4638AC2148753D0FD8A9.description: Christ declared the gospel to the Jewish people (Mark 1:14-15, 38).

9B0A7F01473D4DF482EB4FF985C4D926.description: Jesus Christ is the perfect Prophet (Mark 1:14-15, 38; Isaiah 42:1-4; 49:6; 50:4; Matthew 12:18-20; Hebrews 1:2; Deuteronomy 18:15-19; Acts 3:19-26; John 1:1-18).

E2A58F80D1004BE39F5E4E56F95338AE.description: Jesus Christ fulfills His work through His three offices.

75634BC7BD1E4D9EB384566DE42F2E83.description: The union of Jesus Christ's two natures is a mystery.                                                                                                                                                  Jesus in the incarnation took on a human nature so that Jesus in one person with a fully divine nature with a fully human nature.  He is not a divine spirit in a human person. He is not a mixture of a divine nature and a human nature. Jesus is one person with a divine nature and a human nature.

9EAD3224D784497F9C69BC69A38B0C95.description: The salvation of humans leads to their becoming like Jesus (2 Corinthians 3:18; Romans 8:29).

627E2C1A5B554E90927480CBC3A8BE91.description: Jesus had to be a human in order to be the sacrificial substitute for humans (Hebrew 2:16-17).

6237B46F73F64E43AF40114238DA7BF6.description: Jesus depended on God's Spirit and His Word, as all humans should  (Matthew 4:1-11; 26-39; Mark 1:35).

0939706A3A6445DDAC4EBF42BC49AC82.description: Paul compares and contrasts Jesus with Adam, the first man (1 Corinthians 15:21-22).

099BACF068F74DF9AE33F735DD588823.description: Jesus experienced hunger (Matthew 4:2) thirst (John 19:28), and fatigue (John 4:6).

6DA125C71AB44C44B8C9E23291600696.description: Jesus grew and developed physically, mentally, and spiritually (Luke 2:52).

86D86C2E2F2D4D5686E952762F9B2629.description: Jesus had a human conception and birth (Matthew 1:18, 20, 24; Luke 1:30-35; Galatians 4:4).

7961A217D6A64F7E815609930D682152.description: Jesus Christ is God.  (See the Doctrine of God)

33452EF940244CA997F802885880866D.description: 2. God predicted that in the end His people would have dominion over Satan and his followers.

BE43DFED7A9045EFAE746698352C1229.description: 1.   God predicted that throughout history Satan and his followers ("the seed of the serpent") would be the enemies of God's people ("the seed of the woman").

AAA1DB2910634FADB525555C2DB4C8FA.description: God promised that His people would triumph over evil.

D30DC14A28EA4D098429BC274E00F980.description: God cursed Satan to experience humiliation and defeat.

527D138569204683B353D092DC746BAE.description: Salvation from death and resuce from Satan's bondage is possible only through Christ's death and Resurrection.

EE3D04172D8B48769856C469E2A3A3BC.description: God promised to deliver His people  (Genesis 3:15).

DB19B63436F84143A751C37DBBE0C9E7.description: All humans suffer death and deserve eternal judgement.

85110AA7164F4F42AC9131EB2A2BDF9C.description: All humans naturally serve Satan's purposes.

C73A9BB90FB643DAB03EC5B89ED46F0F.description: All humans are sinful in nature, have lost fellowship with God and commit sinful deeds.

BC581545DE1A4BD3A1F28507F5EF4A64.description: The first sin damaged the entire human race (Romans 5:12, 19).

847E56603BFE460381A14B259F6CF81D.description: Humans relationships are characterized by selfishness and strife (Genesis 3:16).

48B402DBE73C4F99B7C3625E490159B5.description: The physical world resists human attempts at dominion (Genesis 3:16-19; Romans 8:22).

11861848E826454994D07B359A62B1C8.description: The work of dominion was frustrated (cf. Genesis 3:16-19).

70E780DD736E4B95AAD8B1F7014D3B87.description: The mind was darkened (1 Corinthians 2:14; Ephesians 4:17-18).

A5180C29BEB24B719F3037D942B8DBAA.description: The image of God in man was marred (Genesis 3:12-13).

632604A47180427DAA911FFDD23B6992.description: Adam ate from the tree when Eve offered him the fruit(Genesis 3:6).

53604F2236B240E09FB243D4F4DFD8D4.description: Eve ate from the forbidden tree when she decided to trust Satan's word instead of God's word (cf. Genesis 2:17; 3:4, 6).

A938B2E55DBF449A9899EB3FF61C625C.description: Satan told a half truth regarding the conseqnces of disobeying God (Genesis 3:5).

DFF9D381648A461E87BAD755710C43AF.description: Satan appealed to the God-given desire to be like God (cf. Genesis 1:27 and 3:5; cf. Genesis 2:9 and 3:6).

D7BCBE82F7844ABEA8080A3C1D66F232.description: Satan cast doubt on the goodness of God's character (Genesis 3:1).

BA75504409AA42AEA976566B5E0D970B.description: Satan, the enemy of God presented himself as a serpent (cf. Revelation 12:9).

DA2651AC77CD409698EBB97D32E8D15F.description: God promised that if they did eat from this tree, they would die.

2B5A80CADE3C405AB805809AFD5B0BEA.description: God told Adam and Eve not to eat from the tree of the knowledege of good and evil.

C45C516F09F442B89AA61DF34D9B9C62.description: Humans declare God's glory by exercising good and wise dominion over the earth.

8F5E20AC05164249B4110182DFCD5053.description: Although humans are part of God's creation, they stand above the created order as the representatives of God.

1977CDD46DBC4032979A0B151504AC31.description: Man is able to manage God's world under God's authroity becasue he was made in God's image.

6C5D05D5052647E98F585C1B72725FD4.description: God created man with the responsibility to exercise dominion (Genesis 1:26, 28).

082529C675BC46AB91141146EA71CDF9.description: Originally humans were free of pain, sorrow and death.

CEA19ABC03D04189BABEFDBBA8FFD250.description: Originally humans were morally perfect.  They loved God entirely and loved each other as much as self. (cf. Mark 12:30-31)

3DD78136DCAE43F7B5A6015C334E9773.description: God made humans to love and serve Him. Because humans are made in God's image they need to have a relationship with God in order to find fulfillment.

B1D65405546C48FD9CCE519E599A0AE6.description: God made humans to be His great masterpiece.  The rest of creation is remarkable in its beauty, complexity and grandeaur.  However, only humans are said to be made in God's image.

6F27649EE9DA47FD8F4B3D5237EDF874.description: God made humans to be like Himself in many ways.  These include spiritual nature, moral sensitivity, reasoning capacity and the ability to interact with other persons.

E718985FE2BF4C89A35829195D525D8A.description: God Created man in His own image (Genesis 1:26-27).

484E8F46C5614CF081D65AABF3E854C2.description: The purpose of God's governing work is to establish His kingdom on earth so that He may receive glory forever (1 Corinthians 15:28).

CDCEE84187154FEEB2EA78D5BB57E736.description: God's governing work extends over every part of His world, including nature, the nations of the earth and even the choices of individuals (Psalm 135:6-7; Daniel 4:17, 34; Acts 4:28; Ephesians 1:11).

53E3616A86954EE1A7D461F8841F102C.description: God preserves His world by constantly caring for His creatures (Psalm 104:10-13; 145:15).

AE5A269DCC4245F8B5A2B87F0E104670.description: God preserves His world by continuously holding it together (Colossians 1:17; Hebrews 1:3).

97F1BF72EAC147328861AB3AA8756B60.description: Providence       The work of God by which He continually preserves His world and governs it for the fulfillment of His plan.

F7CB498B95F44C97BA3C4B6197C13F88.description: God's creation brought Him pleasure and He still values what He has made.

4EB583B15F6147158A498FCF8E964CA0.description: Evolutionary theory should be rejected because it contradict biblical teaching.

57765200EE0348379814C7BB1D35CD93.description: Everything exists to declare the glory of God.

97B2338D7D3F4371ABF1865F0C7E1F1E.description: God owns everything because He made everything out of nothing.

D87EB7D49DF2457F81207541F9B79935.description: God created everything in six days (Genesis 1; Exodus 20:11).

45FC311D2D1240B39395496064927989.description: God created everything for His own glory (Romans 11:36).

222DA538C8144F179258871F9A9B0040.description: God created the world out of nothing. (Genesis 1:1-26; Psalm 33:6-9; John 1:3; Hebrew 11:3).

754CCC99020343DE9AC01A39484F4CD8.description: Biblical evidence (Genesis 1; Exodus 20:11; Psalm 33:6-9; John 1:3; Hebrews 11:3; Romans 11:36).

D0DA899A5F1D4C8B8CA07F8035128093.description: The doctrine of the Trinity is a mystery.  God's being and character are so great that we can never understand Him fully.  Accepting that He is unltimately unknowable is essential to knowing Him truly.

2F5F1B03713F4593B2BEF9B8D720A657.description: Jesus spoke to the Father , the Son and the Spirit as distinct persons. (Matthew 28:19).

9DDA7A4C356F4E18AC13847AE9EAB483.description: Jesus taught that He was distinct from the Father (John 5:31-40).

D21B789C32684980A13865BA25C3C1A1.description: The Spirit has divine attributes and does divine works (1 Corinthians 2:11-16; Hebrews 9:14; Genesis 1:2; John 3:8; 16:8; Romans 8:14).

AC7EBEF2864F47E2865BFF1422634BF4.description: The Spirit has a status exalted above that of any created thing (Matthew 12:30-31; 28:19).

2F4FC10099094F88A8D7DC6A772C0038.description: Spirit is used interchangeably with God (John 14:16-17, 23; Acts 5:3-4).

6B4C98F6CB314338AB74AD331B1C2F0A.description: The Son does the works that are unique to God (John1:1-3; Colossians 1:16-17;  Hebrews 1:3; 10; John 5:22, 25).

DFEA6B8E513C43D587ED249623778C15.description: The Son is worshiped as God (Psalm 2:10-12; Matthew 8:2; John 5:21-23; Philippians 2:9-10; Hebrews 1:6; Revelation 5:8-14).

4F996C2EF0FD41F381E2493EE87D9F44.description: The Son is called God (Isaiah 9:6; John 1:1; 20:28; Hebrews 1:8).

BD843C30B3F5480A922E3B75CD1C7155.description: Three persons are identified as God.

893520AD3247424A88C83E416145AD4E.description: There is only one God (Deuteronomy 4:35; 6:4; Isaiah 45:5; James 2:19).

08249F523F5A4ED8948B5B81233B3742.description: Tri-unity of God     The doctrine of the Trinity is the biblical teaching that although God is singular in His essence, He exists in three distinct persons: the Father, the Son and the Holy Spirit.  The Bible teaches this in the following ways.

9AB6EB86540A417FBEBB8A1DED4EB04C.description: Love        God is a loving God. He is patient with all sinners. He is kind and merciful to all.  And He is gracious-He shows favor even to those who deserve punishment.  In a fallen world, God's love seems to conflict with His justice.  However, because Jesus died in the sinner's place there is no conflict between God's justice and His love (Exodus 34:5; Psalm 86:5; Acts 14:17; Romans 3:24-26; Ephesians 2:7-9; Peter 3:9; 1 John 4:8).

23B8DB3215684BF29342AEF94B05B83F.description: Justice          God is righteous.  He perfectly lives the moral standard that His character establishes for the world.  He always does what justice demands. He holds His creatures accountable  to do what justice demands.  When His creatures fail to meet their obligations, He punishes them (Exodus 34:6-7; Deuteronomy 32:4; Romans 2:6-8).

B2CC9784C2444886ADC9C74A1DC8059B.description: Truthfulness     God is completely reliable. He cannot lie and He keeps all His promises (Numbers 23:19; Jeremiah 10:9-10; Titus 1:2).

755BC4D952EC431BA19B00591175DD9B.description: Holiness        God is separate from His Creation. He is the most glorious being in the universe, infinitely exalted above all that He has made. God is separate from all sin and evil in this world.  God is both glorious and pure. (Leviticus 22:32; Isaiah 6:1-5; 40:25; Habakkuk 1:13; 1 John 1:5).

C1871083D4F84E8183E74A81D463E7DC.description: Immutability        God is unchangeable in His attributes and His purposes. He will never cease to be what He is. (Psalm 33:11; Malachi 3:6; James 1:17).

6B026CE150774F96B3B8E6D18483CCB2.description: Eternality. God is not limited by time. He has never had a beginning and He will never cease to exist (Deuteronomy  33:27; Psalm 90:2; 102:26-27).

430621364DC34664957E3EEA9C26B842.description: Omnipotence. God is all powerful. He is able to do whatever His perfect will has determined to do.  (Genesis 18:14; Psalm 115:3; Matthew 19:26).

C6E5FB2F3B444397901051BDACCA3662.description: Omniscience. God is infinite in His knowledge.  Knows everything that has happened, is happening and will ever happen. He also knows what may happen but never does happen. (1 Samuel 23:12; Psalm 147:5; Isaiah 46:9-10; Hebrews 4:13).

D008F8904C8A4EA699A923A68F96D2A1.description: Omnipresence. God is independent of space.  God's entire being is present in every place. (Psalm 139:7-10).

6832DFFDFFE24CACB38082CC6EC2FCBB.description: Infinity      God is infinite or unlimited.  God is not limited in His relationship to space, knowledge, power or time.

47739F35056740378511CFCDE2A4C37B.description: God is a spirit being.  He does not have a body.  He is free of all limitations that hinder physical beings.  He is completely self-sufficient. There is nothing in the world that God needs (John 4:24; Acts 17:24-25; 1 Timothy 1:17).

FE66AAF72C8F41C9A43BE69AC5F0B701.description: God testifies to His existence in the created order (Romans 1:20).

9B84B96D1F694265AA0052099C619F2D.description: God testifies to His existence in the Bible (Genesis 1:1).

2CA7E3BC54DE488EBDE2304867267CCB.description: The pseudepigraphal books contain teaching that contradicts the Old Testament Scripture recognized by Jesus and the New Testament Scripture produced by His apostles and prophets.

79DBC622B12D4EE4BAD37E163B9CA1C8.description: The pseudepigraphal books (such as the gospel of Thomas or the Gospel of Judas)  falsely claim to be written by apostles or other prominent early Christians even though they were actually written long after these men were dead.

70CDC97F1A9C44F7AE9FB86C49A3A39E.description: The Aprocrypha contains both factual errors (Judith 1:1) and doctrines contrary to the Old and New Testaments Sirach 3:30).

212848A4F91B4540A53318ADF89BE753.description: The writers of the New Testament often quoted from the Old Testament but never from the Apocrypha.  This implies they did not recognize the Apocrypha as Scripture.

C07DD8636C8140C89CEDE2F6CD0C888A.description: Christ did not recognize the Apocryphal books as authoritative.  Jesus spoke of the Law, the Prophets and the Psalms as scripture (Luke 24:44)  These three labels stood for the thirty-nine books of our Old Testament. Jesus also indicated the canon began with Genesis and ended with 2 Chronicles. In the first century, 2 Chronicles was the 39th book in the Jewish canon (Luke 11:51) .

2EEF568DFFC84B29826D0565717F09D2.description: The Jews of that day did not recognize them as Scripture.

36A94507C9D347B381EE52812A096A40.description: Apocrypha.  (a group of Jewish books written during the intertestamental period)

0C3401DCED3A4D3A9882B5867502CEDC.description: Reasons for rejecting the apocrypha and pseudepigraphical books.

090696E8872E42AFA22F9B9C2A86344C.description: The Bible's self-attestation has led orthodox Chrisitans to recognize the same books as canonical.

27ED8A986B0A4FD99920ECCBF67318B5.description: Certain New Testament books recognize other New Testament books as canonical (cf. 1 Timothy 5:18; Luke 10:7; 2 Peter 3:15-16).

95B935AD6B7F4EC89781D51D3D14E774.description: The New Testament recognizes the Old Testament books as canonical (Matthew 21:42; John 10 35-36; Acts 15:14-18; 17:11;  2 Timothy 3:16-17; 1 Peter 1:23-25).

911E5740FAD64C8F90ADADD28BFD6211.description: The apostles and prophets were the ones to whom God entrusted the revelation concerning Christ and the founding of the Church. (John 16:12-15; Ephesians 2:20) Therefore,  no book subsequent to the generation of the the apostles is considered canonical. (Hebrews 1:1-2; Jude 1:3).

5111EEEA162C4574B955271C2DC9EC35.description: God gave revelation to explain His redemptive acts and to guide His people.

363E8CA389F54BE1ABA855BCE44B875D.description: Orthodoxy- No book that contradicts other scripture can be part of the canon (Isaiah 8:20).

C165AADC7C5941B1A1BE696B7F5BFFD0.description: Not every inspired prophesy  was canonical.  Scripture reveals that  God spoke some words that were not recorded or preserved (2 Corinthians 12:4; Revelation 10:4).

BF96A40185B8415EAD3D37424B7BCCEA.description: Inspiration is the most important criterion for cannonicity. Only words breathed  out by God qualify to be included in the canon (2 Timothy 3:16) .

7DF3CD53EAAF42B7A88783B6B1AC4AFA.description: Definition - Canon refers to the books of the Bible that Christians have recognized as Scripture.

8DCA617CC5204651B1CEE60CCBBFADA2.description: Sufficiency. As the Word of our loving, all-knowing, and holy God, the Bible is sufficient to lead believers to godliness. (Psalm 119:11, 50, 66, 89, 130; 2 Timothy 3:16-17; Revelation 22:18-19)

FF9175A41A884B16AE6C2ADB2AD490C1.description: Authority. Since the Bible is the Word of God, it has the same  authority that God Himself possesses. (Luke 24:25; John 15:20; 1 Thessalonias 2:13; 2 Peter 3:2)

ACF01D147CF644C8807EC5BBAFB0155F.description: Inerrancy.   Because the Bible writers wrote what God wanted written, the Bible-in its original writings -is completely without error (2 Samuel 7:28; Psalm 12:6; John 17:17; Hebrews 6:18).

288D883D35A54A7BAF6BA746784A5099.description: 5.  The Bible has changed millions of lives.

BFAB556506294BC4B594B2B00458835D.description: 4. The Bible has influenced human history more than any other book.

C3399A2A8F384E7CB8172AABCBFDB9E5.description: 3.  The Bible unfolds a unified message even though it was written by many authors over many centuries.

3F68B72991C745DB8093744C9D25056C.description: 2.  Many of the Bible prophecies have already come true.

AE855A876CFA46C9AC841F3EB8FB6879.description: Other evidence for the Bible's inspiration is helpful but is not as convincing as the Bible's testimony concerning itself.

DDE1A0F28B134BC5AE5BD9DCA5539F7C.description: Since the Bible is the Word of God, its own testimony regarding its origin is the most powerful testimony. There is no evidence or testimony that is greater than that.

D552CBC9A82B4DA7BCFBEDE7AD6363E7.description: Those who belong to Christ recognize His words when they read them. (John 10:27)

29CDE000D2464BEAA5677B225046C2EE.description: The things of God are discerned throuh the Spirit and not through natural ability. (1  Corinthians 2:14)

FF46D1EF688D4A1E8186043BFFBB4802.description: The Holy Spirit shows believers that the Bible is God's Word.

239C4A27D9CC40E2B97FAD740C28B2E7.description: The apostle Paul stated that all Scripture is inspired by God. (2 Timothy 3:16)

82C8794A4157477581A859AC9E17F19D.description: The apostle Peter said that the Holy Spirit led the Old Testament writers to write what they wrote. (2 Peter 1:20-21)

5941684135AC4718A1E53BE4919B4CF1.description: The writers use the phrase "thus saith the Lord" hundreds of times. ( Exodus 5:1; Joshua 24:2;  2 Samuel 7:5; Isaiah 7:7)

E6C875B2345844FBBAFE48018B50D1A9.description: The Bible claims to be the Word of God.

3B1A8C19547F4E66B13E3289177DF0BE.description: The supernatural influence of the Holy Spirit on the writers of the Bible so that what they wrote was exactly what God wanted written.
